segments.text: At that time, when you registered, you would go to a specific department and you could ask for a certain section if you knew who the instructor was.
And I followed his advice on numerous occasions.
Who were some of those, for you, some of those special first-year teachers?
Oh, Dr. S.R.
Gammon.

head of the history department, and I majored in history, but I recall, and he said, he told me, he says, I had a B in 105, and he said, if you'll take this exam and make an A, you'll get an A in the course.
And so I took him up on that.

describe dr gammon as a lecturer he was great he came to texas a m to teach history as i remember as was told to me in the southern tradition and he had been a graduate of washington and lee and he he was a fine teacher and he was a little tough sometimes but if you
responded by, you could make a good grade.
I recall I went through with him through my senior year, and one letter quiz my senior year, and I believe it was U.S.
Diplomatic History

some like that i i didn't do very well particular quiz and he wrote me a little bit this is not of your quality and i i i took it part but he was a he was very good teach did he have a nickname i'm not heard one for him
You have not?
No.
Oyster Joe.
Oh, that's right.
That's right.
Yes, yes.
Because of his habit of having peanuts in his mouth and clearing his throat and rolling them around.
That's right.
That's a special one.
Now, his father, I've learned, was a great Presbyterian leader in Kentucky and Virginia, so that he came from a line of preacher teachers.
He was great.
I enjoyed him.
I enjoyed him.
All right.
Other first-year teachers you remember with pride and gratitude?
At A&M.
For example, English.
I'm trying to remember.
I think it was Mr. Key, Mr. P.C.
Key, that I had English.
I never had my father.
I remember that for sure.
But I had Mr. Key and Mr. Gunter and Dr. Summey, who was head of the department.
I enjoyed them.
I think it must have been Mr. Key.
And you know, it's changed now tremendously, but you had to write some compositions and so forth.
And I was able to do pretty well under those instructors.
I'm just trying to...
I had Mr. Wolcott in Spanish.
He was... Say, Jersey Joe?
J.J. Wolcott was in the Modern Language Department, and his activity was also the singing cadets.
He was one of their main directors way back there.
And he taught...
Spanish, and I took two years in college, and that second year when we got to having to read it, well, I didn't do as well as I should have done.
Let's see, math, English, sciences?
I had general science.
The only thing I know, I don't remember those instructors.
I just...

um let's see political science what we now call polit and then it was government we didn't have it was uh government all in the uh history department department and uh of course the toughest teacher in the history department was dr uh dodson he taught
British history.
Oh, he was tough.
He was really tough.
Did he have a nickname?
James Lingle Dodson is the only thing I remember.
That was his name.
But then another famous history prof was Screamin' Al Nelson.
Was he there when you were a student?
He taught Latin American history.
I did not understand why that nickname was applied until I had a class across the hall from him I taught, and I heard him speak very loudly about his feelings about Franklin Roosevelt,
and other communists, he said one day.
And so I understood, let's see, was Horace Bass?
Oh, Dr. Bass, I graded papers for Dr. Bass.
Oh, describe working for him.
He was a fine gentleman.
And I recall I was introduced to him in one of, between my freshman and sophomore year, or sophomore and junior year,
I was going to work at the job that I had and described.
No, I was going to work for the registrar's office.
That's what I was going to do.
And play softball.
And I was rudely detracted when I, in a softball game, I broke a collarbone.
And so then it was time enough for me to go and register and take some courses.
And I took some history electives.
And Dr. Bass taught those that summer, and then later in my junior year, I graded some of his papers.
You know, everybody had to take 306 Government, and it wasn't too difficult for a liberal arts major
to grade an ag or engineering student's government paper.
So I did that for him, and he was fine.
He was fine.
Do you remember what your compensation was as a grader then?
Oh, I don't.
I couldn't have been very much.
Do you remember what the cost was for a year at A&M in those days?
I do recall when I believe I registered the...
Matriculation fee was $50 a semester, as I recall.
And that meant you could take 16 to 18 hours of work.
And then you lived at home, and so you had to buy your books.
Books, uniform.
And it's amazing.
There would be no comparison to what you have for education today.
Let's see.
When did you decide that law was your calling?
I had always wanted to take law, and I would read.
In the 30s, there was a great deal written
in the South about anti-lynching laws.
And, of course, that was legislative in nature, and I just picked up on that and I said, well, I want to be a legislator.
Of course, I never was, but I knew that if I had to take pre-law before you could go to law school, so I took liberal arts at A&M.
Now, you were in the Corps, but you lived at home.
Describe the Corps routine for you living at home.
I participated in all of the military activities.
I'd drill with my unit.
I would report to the unit.
a gun in the gun room that I had to keep clean, and I participated in the extra drills that the unit had, and completed all of those activities, you see.
And I maintained and got a contract my junior year
It meant that you would take advanced ROTC, and I received a contract and was on the course for reserve commission upon graduation.
As a freshman, to what outfit were you assigned?
F Coastal Artillery.
What was their nickname?
Had no nickname.
Like they do, we had Coastal Artillery Regiment.
There was an Artillery Regiment, Infantry Regiment, Composite Regiment, all of those.
We had no Air Force, as is known today.
It was much different.
Were any of those Army branches higher in student prestige or lower?
Which one was supposedly the choice?
Well, okay.
In the Coast Artillery Regiment, you had primarily engineers.
In the infantry regiment, you had agricultural students.
In the Signal Corps, you had electrical engineers, you see.
And that was more or less, and you could ask for a specific, and I knew some, there was another local man in the,
in the Coastal Artillery that I knew, C.A.
Lewis, and I said, well, I'd like to go in there.
And so you could request a preference, and they assigned me.
Though I was really out of place when it came to the...
Though I had to take college trigonometry to qualify, so I got through that, but I couldn't compete with the engineers.
Describe, during that freshman year, describe the routine of a typical day, weekday.
What time did things begin and what did you do?
Well, you had an 8 to 5, or 8 to 12, 1 to 5.
The whistle blew at 8 o'clock and it blew at 12, 1, and 5.
And that was the schedule.
As a freshman, you were, and they don't have that distinction now, we wore a little white stripe around our left sleeve.
And you walked in the street.
You didn't walk on the sidewalk.
You didn't have any other privileges.
But you went to class, see.
And everybody was in uniform.
And you had drills.
once a week for two hours, and you would go to the armory and participate, whatever was on the training schedule.
And 12 noon whistle blows, everything stops, takes up at one o'clock, and terminates at five.
Now did you drill with your outfit before they went to supper?
If there were a scheduled drill, we'd have, we had special occasions like that where you'd have manual of arms drills and anything that was called.
If you wanted to kind of hide out and not be found, where did you go?
Everybody went to the YMCA.
reading room or to the library.
And I understand that by and large no one hazed anybody or harassed them in either of those places.
No, that didn't occur.
That in fact you could even kind of find a quiet place in the library and maybe take a brief nap.
You could.
The seats were hard, though, the chairs.
Let's see.
Did you eat many meals in the dining hall those first two years?
No, sir.
No, sir, I didn't.
Did you ever take some buddies home for meals?
Oh, yeah.
On occasions, they would come over, and mostly they were study sessions.
They would come over, and we would...
I remember, well, they were all liberal arts, and you know, you would be in the same section for any number of different courses, you see.
You'd have the same students would be in that section.
Now, were there some courses that everybody kind of feared that were kind of tough, tough, tough courses, and everybody knew they were?
Well, not for the liberal arts student as much as for the engineering students, you know.
They had some tough courses.
They had calculus, you know, and then they had some of the advanced engineering courses.
I just hear them talk about it.
Now, what math did you have to take?
I went through trigonometry.
So kind of a repeat of what you'd had in high school?
In high school, it was.
Who taught that?
Do you remember?
I think it must have been Mr. Lyle taught.
All right, so your routine then as a sophomore did not change much.
Did not change much.
Then I went into the dormitory in my junior year, and...
Then my senior year I was in the dorm, and I was elected editor of the battalion my senior year, and I had that particular duty to look after.
Let's hold that, because I want to be sure to talk about that, but let's go back to the fall of 1939.
the Aggies had a fairly good football team.
Describe some of those star players as human beings.
Well, the outstanding player was John Kimbrough, who developed in his sophomore year about the middle of the season
He rose to the top.
And so for the 1939 year, he was the main show, and he was a terrific football player.
On that same team were, well, Bama Smith, I saw him the other day.
He was a senior on that team, as I recall.
and he lives around here now, and did a whole lot to help beat Texas when they played over here that year, that fall.
And then A&M later played in the Sugar Bowl against Tulane, and it was Cotton Price, the quarterback, and well, Pugh was the next year, and Thomason, the blocking back, Herbie Smith,
Oh, there were quite a few of those guys.
They were quite a team.
Was Kimbrough respected as a fellow Aggie?
Oh, yes.
He was over in the infantry regiment along with his brother Jack.
He played on that same team and all.
And then...
All of those men were, those players were in the Corps, though they lived maybe at one time in a special dorm.
But then again, they went back to the Corps.
They dissolved that athletic dormitory concept.
But they were all true A&M men and did well.
And did the athletes in that era, in your era, go to class and graduate?
Oh, yeah.
Except there was one, you know, there was a famous guard, Marshal Rob Nett.
A&M at that time had what they called a
what do they call, grade, not grade, well, you could end up with minus grade points if you didn't attend class.
And he played for three years or four years, but he ended up with minus grade points.
But that was just the nature of it.
What about Coach Norton?
Describe him.
Coach Norton came way back in the middle 30s to lead A&M out of the wilderness, so to speak.
And he brought Dick Todd with him, but that was before this big 39 team.
Todd had completed in 38, I believe, and didn't play on the 39 team, but he was a great player.
And Uncle Bill James was his line coach.
Doe Rollins was an assistant coach.
Manning Smith was the backfield coach.
And...
They put it all together in 39, and Coach Norton went to the Sugar Bowl, and then the next year we were going to go to the Rose Bowl, but we got sidetracked in Austin.
I need that to happen.
Yeah.
Well, many of them were inducted into the service at the Cotton Bowl game in...
where Kate Smith sang God Bless America.
So a lot of those guys were inducted right there at the half.
All right.
As a freshman in 1939, that great team, do you remember going on court trip?
Court trip?
I remember going to the Sugar Bowl game.
Oh, in 1940.
Please describe that trip.
That was a great trip.
I was able to go and have a room with a friend of mine named Joe Orr, whose dad was in the CE department.
And little Joe and I went down there, and I got him a ticket, and he got me a place to stay, and we had a great time.
That was the greatest football game I've ever seen.
How did you all get there?
We got there on the train.
That was the only way you could go.
And, well, you could drive and all, but most people traveled by train.
And, of course, life in the French Quarter in celebration of New Year's is quite an occasion, too.
You know, it's wall-to-wall on Canal Street, and that was quite an experience, too.
The football game was probably the best one that I have ever seen.
Kimbrough and Price beat Kellogg and McCollum, who were all Americans for Tulane, 14 to 13.
And that's where, that's made A&M football.
And then the next year, it was going to be even greater, but naturally the war was developing and all, and a lot of those guys, well, they still,
they dropped out and then actually, going back to Jimmy Cashin, he was in the kiddie corps that Norton coached probably in the years 44 and 45, maybe 43, I don't know.
But Jimmy was in school then and he played quarterback for
for Norton then.
And, well, of course, when you think about, there's only one thing to think about now is when and how were you going.
A lot of guys would leave A&M at the end of the sophomore year and go into the service.
And one of the primary places they would go would be to, it took two
semesters of college work to get into the flying program.
And a lot of guys would go then, and then if they didn't do well in school, they would, you know, the other opportunity was to go into the service.
And we were inducted, or my class was inducted, because we went to school in the summer of 42, and graduated in January of 43.
We were wholesale, the whole class took a special train

from Bryan, our college station, to Houston to be inducted in the inducting schedule and then came back and graduated and then were called to active duties as enlisted personnel and then we all went to
OCS and then got our commissions.
Let's back up to December 7, 1941.
Where were you and how did you hear what had happened at Pearl Harbor?
It was a Sunday afternoon, and I remember it was a nice day and all, and the word came out, okay, and of course, that what had happened, you know, came by radio.
Everybody said, well, let's go.
And some of them sure left at that time.
Do you remember anybody having any reservation about what the United States should do?
Oh, there was no reservation about it.
And in the Cadet Corps, well, you know, well, do I go now or do I wait?
And most of them, naturally, waited.
But quite a few just left.
Did your parents have any words for you that you remember right at that point?
Nothing.
They knew I was part of it, and they couldn't control it.
So you were, this is your third year, the fall of your?
Fall of 41.
So if you started 39, then the fall of 40?
I remember the class of 42.
They went wholesale.
Then I was the next class.
So you were the class of 43.
And when did y'all learn that the four-year routine was going to be shortened?
I guess in the spring of 42.
And the college went on full time around the clock, and they had no facilities to go to summer camp.
So that meant that the only thing you could do would be to go to school, and then they didn't know what would happen thereafter.
That's what happened.
We went to school.
All right, and you were living on campus then as a junior.
I was living in the dormitory, and I was editor of the battalion for the summer of 42 and the fall of 43.
Describe what...
There was very little going on.
Your battalion...
In the summer.
Oh, the battalion?
Yes.
It was interesting.
We had...
three issues a week, Tuesday, Thursday, Saturday.
I believe, yeah, we had three issues a week.
We were under supervision of the Student Activities Office, and it was pretty hard sometimes to fill out
with newsprint, you know.
Who was the key individual advisor?
Or the key person that you... Well, that's a good question there.
I think Mr. Angel was the assistant to the president.
Is this Charlie Angel?
E.L. Angel.
Oh.
And he had...
the student activities supervisor was Mr. Boone, I think.
He had the actual hands-on.
But Mr. Angel was the administrative overseer, you might say.
And we had a lot of
Well, there wasn't a whole lot of activity because then you were locked in then.
By that time, you couldn't travel.
There was not much athletic activity in the summer, and I remember my sports editor was Mike Hyken.
And he made a mountain out of a molehill by writing up every softball game that occurred on the campus.
That's what he did to cover sports, because there wasn't anything until the fall, and football came.
We still had a football season and all.
But we went to school, wore the uniform, and that was a little unusual for that summer.
How were you selected as the editor?
I was the student body.
Okay.
And was there any compensation at all other than satisfaction?
$55 a month.
I believe that's what it was.
And where was the battalion located, quartered?
In the basement of the administration building.
Because the press, the...
N.M. Press was in the north end of that basement building.
And just down the other, in the south hall, was the student activities office.
About where did the battalion circulate?
Primarily to the dormitories and the faculty.
and then some mail outs to selected, I think each staff member had two subscriptions that they could send.
Did you ever publish anything that was close to being questionable by any reviewer?
Oh yes, I remember during my,
services, the editor.
There was a monthly magazine of feature stories, and it had a different editor.
John Holman was the managing editor of that.
And it had jokes in it.
And we would take selected jokes
from other magazines, other student publications across the country.
And as I recall, Mr. Angel reviewed one of those magazines, and he questioned me about the quality of the jokes.
Maybe he said they were too off color.
And I said, well, I'm going to go along with the managing editor.
He thinks they're all right.
But the next thing I knew, that that whole addition, before it was bound and cut, was on the garbage.
